title.value: Learning from unexpected events in the neocortical microcircuit
title.justification: The title is taken directly from the top of the research paper.
title.quote: Learning from unexpected events in the neocortical microcircuit

extractions.description: This paper shows that both somata and distal apical dendrites of cortical pyramidal neurons exhibit distinct unexpected event signals that evolve over days. These findings were obtained using two-photon calcium imaging to track the responses of individual somata and dendritic branches of layer 2/3 and layer 5 pyramidal neurons in the primary visual cortex of awake, behaving mice.

type.justification: The paper involves experimental procedures like two-photon calcium imaging and behavioral experiments with mice.
type.quote: These findings were obtained by tracking the responses of individual somata and dendritic branches of layer 2/3 and layer 5 pyramidal neurons over multiple days in primary visual cortex of awake, behaving mice using two-photon calcium imaging.

name.justification: The research focuses on the neocortical microcircuit and pyramidal neurons, indicative of the field of neuroscience.
name.quote: Scientists have long conjectured that the neocortex learns the structure of the environment in a predictive, hierarchical manner.

name.justification: The paper discusses theoretical models of hierarchical predictive learning in the neocortex and references models like predictive coding.
name.quote: This is a central component of a broad class of theories in neuroscience and machine learning that postulate that the brain learns a hierarchical model of the world by comparing predictions about sensory stimuli to the actual stimuli received from the world.

name.justification: The study utilizes two-photon calcium imaging, which is a common technique in the field of neural imaging.
name.quote: These findings were obtained using two-photon calcium imaging to track the responses of individual somata and dendritic branches of layer 2/3 and layer 5 pyramidal neurons.

name.justification: The paper references the hierarchical predictive coding model to explain its hypotheses and findings.
name.quote: According to this conjecture, expected, predictable features are differentiated from unexpected ones by comparing bottom-up and top-down streams of information.

is_contributed.justification: The model itself is not a contribution of this paper but rather a referenced model used to frame the study.
is_contributed.quote: Scientists have long conjectured that the neocortex learns the structure of the environment in a predictive, hierarchical manner.

is_executed.justification: The model is used conceptually to frame the study but is not executed computationally in the research.
is_executed.quote: Scientists have long conjectured that the neocortex learns the structure of the environment in a predictive, hierarchical manner.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not compare this model numerically to other models.
is_compared.quote: Theoretical support for this hypothesis comes from computational studies showing that hierarchical models that learn by comparing top-down signals to bottom-up signals enable artificial neural networks (ANNs) to learn useful representations that capture the statistical structure of the data on which they are trained.

referenced_paper_title.value: Predictive coding in the visual cortex: a functional interpretation of some extra-classical receptive-field effects
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Rao and Ballard is one of the seminal papers on hierarchical predictive coding referenced in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: A long-standing hypothesis in computational and systems neuroscience is that the neocortex learns a hierarchical predictive model of the world [Dayan et al., 1995; Friston and Kiebel, 2009; Hawkins and Blakeslee, 2004; Larochelle and Hinton, 2010; Press et al., 2020; Rao and Ballard, 1999; Spratling, 2017; Whittington and Bogacz, 2017].

name.justification: The paper specifically mentions the use of data collected as part of the Allen Institute for Brain Science’s OpenScope initiative.
name.quote: The dataset used in this paper was collected as part of the Allen Institute for Brain Science’s OpenScope initiative.

referenced_paper_title.value: A large-scale standardized physiological survey reveals functional organization of the mouse visual cortex
referenced_paper_title.justification: This reference paper describes the Allen Brain Observatory data which is used in the study.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Data were collected and processed using the Allen Brain Observatory data collection and processing pipelines [de Vries et al., 2020].

name.justification: The paper used DeepLabCut for tracking the pupils in the mouse behavior experiments.
name.quote: We trained a DeepLabCut model from ∼200 manually labeled examples to automatically label points around the eye, from which we estimated the pupil diameter [∼0.01 mm per pixel conversion].

referenced_paper_title.value: DeepLabCut: markerless pose estimation of user-defined body parts with deep learning
referenced_paper_title.justification: This paper by Mathis et al., describes DeepLabCut, which is used in the study for pupil tracking.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We trained a DeepLabCut model from ∼200 manually labeled examples to automatically label points around the eye, from which we estimated the pupil diameter [∼0.01 mm per pixel conversion] [Mathis et al., 2018].
